relationships.description: Operations Manager who worked on Epstein's island
Maxwell described as recruiting girls for Epstein

analysis.purpose: To forward a legal inquiry response and demonstrate refusal to cooperate with investigation
analysis.significance: Shows Epstein's legal team monitoring inquiries about his activities and staff refusing to cooperate with victim's attorney

notable_quotes: At this stage we do not feel it is beneficial and may negatively impact our privacy to answer the questions.
Please respect our request not to assist.
In the cases where statements are credited to [us] I can honestly say that we cannot agree to the statements made
red_flags: Former employees refusing to cooperate with investigation

blackmail_indicators.description: No evidence of blackmail or coercion in this communication

illegal_activity.description: This is legal correspondence forwarding an inquiry response, not evidence of first-hand illegal activity

details: References to previous media interviews and articles about Epstein/Maxwell
Mentions of unwanted media attention from previous interviews

public_knowledge.context: This appears to be internal legal correspondence about Epstein investigation that was later released by House Oversight Committee

analysis.summary: Attorney Darren Indyke forwards an email to Jeffrey Epstein showing that Miles Alexander, an operations manager who worked on Epstein's island, is refusing to cooperate with attorney Brad Edwards' investigation into sexual abuse allegations. Alexander states answering questions would negatively impact their privacy and they cannot agree with statements previously attributed to them in media reports.
